summary: I see so much hate directed at Brie Larson and I just don't get why. You don't find her funny. Ok. You don't like her. Ok. You...
body: I see so much hate directed at Brie Larson and I just don’t get why. You don’t find her funny. Ok. You don’t like her. Ok. You find her annoying. Ok I guess but there are actual videos on YouTube that are like “Compilation of EVERYONE OF THE ENDGAME CAST ABSOLUTELY LOATHING EVERY MINUTE THEY HAVE TO SPEND WITH BRIE LARSON” and then the comments are even worse and I just don’t get it. I have not seen one interview in which Brie was “cringey”, arrogant (at least not more than her co-stars and not in a not-humorous way) and I never felt like her interview partners hated her. Is misogyny really that hell of a drug?

I have not seen one interview in which Brie was “cringey”, arrogant (at least not more than her co-stars and not in a not-humorous way) and I never felt like her interview partners hated her. Is misogyny really that hell of a drug?

Is misogyny really that hell of a drug?

summary: Beast Kingdom Enters Endgame With New PREVIEWS Exclusive Egg Attack, Mini Egg Attack Figures
title: Beast Kingdom Enters Endgame With New PREVIEWS Exclusive Egg Attack, Mini Egg Attack Figures
body:
Beast Kingdom Enters Endgame With New PREVIEWS Exclusive Egg Attack, Mini Egg Attack Figures #Endgame

Just a week before Avengers: Endgame hits theaters, Beast Kingdom is rewarding fans with a new line of PREVIEWSExclusive Mini Egg Attack figures featuring Captain Marvel, Captain America and Iron Man and two new PREVIEWSExclusive Egg Attack Action figures featuring Ronin and Black Widow! 

Featuring fan favorites from the most anticipated superhero movie of the year to life, Beast Kingdom is…

tags: i know nothing about green lantern
summary: five times carol comes back to earth and one time maria goes to space
title: five times carol comes back to earth and one time maria goes to space
body:
[ @racethewind10 is to thank for this ]  

one 

it’s nearly monica’s birthday and carol arrives back in lousiana precisely at one minute to midnight. a closer call than she would like, but she’s still early - if only by forty eight seconds. the summer night is sticky and warm, the stars shine bright in the sky and carol feels a settling in her stomach - she’s home. this is her first time back since shedding yon-rogg and the kree. as predicted, monica comes barreling out from the house, storming through the backyard and flinging herself into carol’s arms. 

“aunt carol, you’re back!” she says, nearly shouts, with a broad grin. 

“of course i am.” carol says, catching the eye of maria, who is wandering out from the house with a beer in her hand. 

carol opens her mouth to say something, but when she see’s maria’s smile, carol realises that she doesn’t have to say anything. not yet. she keeps one arm wrapped around monica, and uses the other to pull maria into a one-armed hug “hey there.” she says “miss me?” 

“please.” maria scoffs, but it’s fond. it’s a yes. 

two  

carol has promised dinner. she has promised maria dinner and in order to cook dinner, there is a prerequisite of being present on earth. it was, in fact, a fundamental aspect of the entire evening going according to plan. the plan that included monica spending the night at her grandparents before being surprised with carol’s arrival the following afternoon. 

but for the night, and the morning, carol and maria were to have nothing but the pleasure of each others company. 

or, that is the plan. 

the plan that involves carol being on earth. 

now, normally, carol takes great pleasure in organising her world saving calendar around the important events in her families lives. she’s missed enough milestones and date nights for a lifetime thank you very much. which is why the beast she’s currently fighting is really getting on her nerves. he’s fast, which is nothing that carol can’t handle, it’s just that she’s distracted because midway through pummelling one of this monsters several heads into the dirt, she had realised something. 

something critical. 

she had forgotten to get maria a replacement anniversary present. 

she had bought one, a few planets back. it had been perfect. until, of course, the beast in front of her, had smashed it with an errant flick of its behemoth of a tail. which was annoying. 

so now, not only did carol have to kill this hydra looking serpent thing that had a tendency to feed on the inhabitants of a planet many light-years from earth. she also had to, somewhere, somehow, find an anniversary gift for maria. it’s not as if these planets have gift shops. 

what they did have was local craftspeople, and maybe that was a place to start. 

three 

nearly a three quarters of a decade ago carol gave two important people, two different pagers. until this moment, carol has never heard from either of them - which considering they were for emergencies only, was a relief. a relief carol had always sought comfort in. until now. 

until the pager she had given to maria and monica is sending her an alert a little scrambled by distance. carol doesn’t need the specifics, not yet, her promise was always the same. when the pager went off, she could get back to earth as fast as she possibly could. which, considering her abilities, was pretty damn fast. panic sat the edges carols consciousness as she plummeted into the earths atmosphere at a rate that would have most radars clock her as a chunk of space debris. a key to coming and going as she pleased without s.h.i.e.l.d or anyone else catching wind of her. 

not that she didn’t like fury, but family was always her priority. 

a family who could currently be in danger or - 

it’s not danger that carol senses when she lands on the dirt road just up from her home. it’s something else, something less tangible, something she’s used to feeling when she lands on wrecked and battered planets. 

grief. 

her stomach jumps into her throat and carol is running up the drive until she sees monica running down the porch steps. part of carol is relieved, yet part of her worry ratchets even higher. 

what if it’s - 

she cuts the thought there and tries to read monica’s face before she starts talking. except it’s no use. monica is blurting 

“it’s nana,” before carol can pick up on anything. 

the words both relieve carols panic and instill her at once with a deeper sadness. monica’s mother, or nana as she was known to monica, had taken carol in and welcomed her like one of her own. 

monica continues “i know you said the pager was for emergencies only and i know momma told me not to call you, but, but she’s so sad.” 

carol pulls monica into her arms - she’s grown so much that she can press a kiss to monica’s forehead without stooping “you did the right thing.” she promises “where’s your mom?” 

“in the kitchen.” monica replies, her voice wet. 

“let’s go find her.” carol says, keeping an arm around monica’s shoulders and guiding her back inside. 

maria is sitting in the kitchen with the radio playing. the song is lost on carol, her entire being focuses solely on her wife. zeroing in on the grief radiating away from her in waves. 

“hey,” she says from the doorway, giving maria a chance to process her presence.

“carol,” maria gasps, turning to look from carol to monica and back again “carol, how-” 

“not important.” carol promises, stepping forward into the room as maria stands. 

she acts on instinct, pulling maria into her arms. she can only imagine how much maria has already cried, but those tears roll down her cheeks anew as carol whispers “i’m so sorry.” into her ear, holding her tight. 

four 

carol is sure she has never been so proud. watching monica stand on stage and give her valedictorian speech. she’s sitting on a metal bleacher in the stadium of the high school. she’s sitting next to her wife watching her daughter graduate from high school at the top of her class. or, if anyone else asks, she’s sitting next to her best friend, watching her goddaughter graduate. 

it’s hardly a lie, but it’s lie enough to keep them all protected. 

maria’s pinky finger twitches, touching against carols for a beat. it’s hardly the hand holding they want, but in this setting, it’s everything. she glances sideways, sharing a tear-filled smile with her wife. this is, without a doubt, one of the best days of her life, of that carol is sure. 

five 

“tell me what happened.” carol says, standing in front of her distraught daughter. 

of course, her words sound as if she’s under control of her emotions. when in fact the reality is something vastly different. there is something like uninhibited rage coursing through her veins. her daughter, her planet, is in meltdown mode as apparently half the population has vanished. carol assumes fury is amongst the unlucky half or she would have heard from him as soon as she had entered the atmosphere. sure, she’d gotten his page. but she’d gotten monica’s a moment before and her daughter, her family, always has priority. 

“she just, disintegrated.” monica says through trembling words “right there across the table.” 

carol glances at the ash and then looks away. 

fuck. 

“she said she didn’t feel so good. thought it was the eggs. but,” monica shakes her head, lost for words. 

carol tugs her into tight hug “i’ll fix this.” she promises, it’s been a long time since a mission held such personal stakes “i’ll fix this.” 

“you have to find the avengers.” monica tells her “they’ll know what happened.” 

carol blinks, “the who now?”

“the avengers.” 

well that was another reason to fix this mess, so she could kill fury all over again for naming his special task force the goddamn avengers. 

+ one  

“so i found this weird ring.” maria says, unexpectedly one morning over breakfast “this morning, with the chickens.” 

carol blinks at her, confused. perhaps it’s the lack of caffeine “okay.” she says “we’re already married, but-” 

“i don’t think this is a wedding ring.” maria says, placing a silver and green ring down on the countertop. 

carol studies it - the insignia on the top of the ring seems vaguely familiar, a circluar shape with a line on either side. 

“what do you think?” maria asks. 

“well,” carol says, her brain processing a few things very rapidly “for one, i think we’ve got a wormhole problem in the chicken coop. and for another, i think you may be the only green lantern in this dimension.” 

“the only who?”

“green lantern.” carol says “pretty cool bunch, telepathic powers attached to the ring. they usually stick to a few dimensions over. not sure what one of their rings is doing here.” 

“so you’re saying the ring gives them powers?” maria looks down at the ring, unconvinced. 

“from what they said it’s more about the willpower of the person wearing the ring, and considering you’re the most stubborn person i know, that thing should be supercharged.” 

“carol what are you saying?” 

“i’m saying your a superhero now. or something. and that monica is going to be so jealous you get to come into space with me.”

[ @racethewind10 is to thank for this ]  

one 

it’s nearly monica’s birthday and carol arrives back in lousiana precisely at one minute to midnight. a closer call than she would like, but she’s still early - if only by forty eight seconds. the summer night is sticky and warm, the stars shine bright in the sky and carol feels a settling in her stomach - she’s home. this is her first time back since shedding yon-rogg and the kree. as predicted, monica comes barreling out from the house, storming through the backyard and flinging herself into carol’s arms. 

“aunt carol, you’re back!” she says, nearly shouts, with a broad grin. 

“of course i am.” carol says, catching the eye of maria, who is wandering out from the house with a beer in her hand. 

carol opens her mouth to say something, but when she see’s maria’s smile, carol realises that she doesn’t have to say anything. not yet. she keeps one arm wrapped around monica, and uses the other to pull maria into a one-armed hug “hey there.” she says “miss me?” 

“please.” maria scoffs, but it’s fond. it’s a yes. 

[[MORE]]

two  

carol has promised dinner. she has promised maria dinner and in order to cook dinner, there is a prerequisite of being present on earth. it was, in fact, a fundamental aspect of the entire evening going according to plan. the plan that included monica spending the night at her grandparents before being surprised with carol’s arrival the following afternoon. 

but for the night, and the morning, carol and maria were to have nothing but the pleasure of each others company. 

or, that is the plan. 

the plan that involves carol being on earth. 

now, normally, carol takes great pleasure in organising her world saving calendar around the important events in her families lives. she’s missed enough milestones and date nights for a lifetime thank you very much. which is why the beast she’s currently fighting is really getting on her nerves. he’s fast, which is nothing that carol can’t handle, it’s just that she’s distracted because midway through pummelling one of this monsters several heads into the dirt, she had realised something. 

something critical. 

she had forgotten to get maria a replacement anniversary present. 

she had bought one, a few planets back. it had been perfect. until, of course, the beast in front of her, had smashed it with an errant flick of its behemoth of a tail. which was annoying. 

so now, not only did carol have to kill this hydra looking serpent thing that had a tendency to feed on the inhabitants of a planet many light-years from earth. she also had to, somewhere, somehow, find an anniversary gift for maria. it’s not as if these planets have gift shops. 

what they did have was local craftspeople, and maybe that was a place to start. 

three 

nearly a three quarters of a decade ago carol gave two important people, two different pagers. until this moment, carol has never heard from either of them - which considering they were for emergencies only, was a relief. a relief carol had always sought comfort in. until now. 

until the pager she had given to maria and monica is sending her an alert a little scrambled by distance. carol doesn’t need the specifics, not yet, her promise was always the same. when the pager went off, she could get back to earth as fast as she possibly could. which, considering her abilities, was pretty damn fast. panic sat the edges carols consciousness as she plummeted into the earths atmosphere at a rate that would have most radars clock her as a chunk of space debris. a key to coming and going as she pleased without s.h.i.e.l.d or anyone else catching wind of her. 

not that she didn’t like fury, but family was always her priority. 

a family who could currently be in danger or - 

it’s not danger that carol senses when she lands on the dirt road just up from her home. it’s something else, something less tangible, something she’s used to feeling when she lands on wrecked and battered planets. 

grief. 

her stomach jumps into her throat and carol is running up the drive until she sees monica running down the porch steps. part of carol is relieved, yet part of her worry ratchets even higher. 

what if it’s - 

she cuts the thought there and tries to read monica’s face before she starts talking. except it’s no use. monica is blurting 

“it’s nana,” before carol can pick up on anything. 

the words both relieve carols panic and instill her at once with a deeper sadness. monica’s mother, or nana as she was known to monica, had taken carol in and welcomed her like one of her own. 

monica continues “i know you said the pager was for emergencies only and i know momma told me not to call you, but, but she’s so sad.” 

carol pulls monica into her arms - she’s grown so much that she can press a kiss to monica’s forehead without stooping “you did the right thing.” she promises “where’s your mom?” 

“in the kitchen.” monica replies, her voice wet. 

“let’s go find her.” carol says, keeping an arm around monica’s shoulders and guiding her back inside. 

maria is sitting in the kitchen with the radio playing. the song is lost on carol, her entire being focuses solely on her wife. zeroing in on the grief radiating away from her in waves. 

“hey,” she says from the doorway, giving maria a chance to process her presence.

“carol,” maria gasps, turning to look from carol to monica and back again “carol, how-” 

“not important.” carol promises, stepping forward into the room as maria stands. 

she acts on instinct, pulling maria into her arms. she can only imagine how much maria has already cried, but those tears roll down her cheeks anew as carol whispers “i’m so sorry.” into her ear, holding her tight. 

four 

carol is sure she has never been so proud. watching monica stand on stage and give her valedictorian speech. she’s sitting on a metal bleacher in the stadium of the high school. she’s sitting next to her wife watching her daughter graduate from high school at the top of her class. or, if anyone else asks, she’s sitting next to her best friend, watching her goddaughter graduate. 

it’s hardly a lie, but it’s lie enough to keep them all protected. 

maria’s pinky finger twitches, touching against carols for a beat. it’s hardly the hand holding they want, but in this setting, it’s everything. she glances sideways, sharing a tear-filled smile with her wife. this is, without a doubt, one of the best days of her life, of that carol is sure. 

five 

“tell me what happened.” carol says, standing in front of her distraught daughter. 

of course, her words sound as if she’s under control of her emotions. when in fact the reality is something vastly different. there is something like uninhibited rage coursing through her veins. her daughter, her planet, is in meltdown mode as apparently half the population has vanished. carol assumes fury is amongst the unlucky half or she would have heard from him as soon as she had entered the atmosphere. sure, she’d gotten his page. but she’d gotten monica’s a moment before and her daughter, her family, always has priority. 

“she just, disintegrated.” monica says through trembling words “right there across the table.” 

carol glances at the ash and then looks away. 

fuck. 

“she said she didn’t feel so good. thought it was the eggs. but,” monica shakes her head, lost for words. 

carol tugs her into tight hug “i’ll fix this.” she promises, it’s been a long time since a mission held such personal stakes “i’ll fix this.” 

“you have to find the avengers.” monica tells her “they’ll know what happened.” 

carol blinks, “the who now?”

“the avengers.” 

well that was another reason to fix this mess, so she could kill fury all over again for naming his special task force the goddamn avengers. 

+ one  

“so i found this weird ring.” maria says, unexpectedly one morning over breakfast “this morning, with the chickens.” 

carol blinks at her, confused. perhaps it’s the lack of caffeine “okay.” she says “we’re already married, but-” 

“i don’t think this is a wedding ring.” maria says, placing a silver and green ring down on the countertop. 

carol studies it - the insignia on the top of the ring seems vaguely familiar, a circluar shape with a line on either side. 

“what do you think?” maria asks. 

“well,” carol says, her brain processing a few things very rapidly “for one, i think we’ve got a wormhole problem in the chicken coop. and for another, i think you may be the only green lantern in this dimension.” 

“the only who?”

“green lantern.” carol says “pretty cool bunch, telepathic powers attached to the ring. they usually stick to a few dimensions over. not sure what one of their rings is doing here.” 

“so you’re saying the ring gives them powers?” maria looks down at the ring, unconvinced. 

“from what they said it’s more about the willpower of the person wearing the ring, and considering you’re the most stubborn person i know, that thing should be supercharged.” 

“carol what are you saying?” 

“i’m saying your a superhero now. or something. and that monica is going to be so jealous you get to come into space with me.”
trail.content:

summary: This video relates to this week’s course material because of how it highlights the effects of online trolls. Captain Marvel’s...
caption: This video relates to this week’s course material because of how it highlights the effects of online trolls. Captain Marvel’s opening weekend was “the sixth biggest worldwide debut of all time” (ET Canada, 2019). This video discusses how online trolls are attempting to ruin films’ ratings, even before the films come out. Rotten Tomatoes has changed their policy on pre-scoring movies and they are on the lookout for online trolls. The reporters cite Black Panther, Captain Marvel, and the latest Star Wars film as examples of films whose ratings were influenced by trolls and bots. These films’ viewer ratings, Rotten Tomatoes ratings, and box office numbers do not correlate correctly.

summary: I saw Shazam! today and it was okay, I guess, but the tone was off throughout the entire movie.  A movie based on Captain...
body:
I saw Shazam! today and it was okay, I guess, but the tone was off throughout the entire movie.  A movie based on Captain Marvel, the Big Red Cheese, should have been fun.  It should have had the optimism of childhood, not the cynicism of a child trying to act mature.

Billy Batson starts the movie as a self-centered jerk and stays that way throughout almost its entire run.  Even his one moment of heroism before getting the powers is self-centered and based around his own issues.  He’s not pure of heart or spirit.  And yes his life has been tough and isolating and vicious, and I’m not saying what he’s been through is something you can just shrug off, but the entire point of his character is supposed to be his continued brightness despite all that he has been through.   There were jokes throughout, and there were some lighthearted scenes of Billy screwing around with his powers as he and Freddy figured them out, but they were isolated moments of levity instead of being the basis of the story.

I’ve got some issues with the Justice League Unlimited episode “The Clash”, but at least they captured what he’s supposed to be about.

Plus, the Wizard is flat-out responsible for Sivana turning into a villain, no ifs-ands-or-buts.  It’s going to fuck up any kid to be whisked away by a wizard and told that he would never be worthy, even if he wasn’t in a car crash immediately afterwards that his jerk father and brother blame on him.

Billy Batson starts the movie as a self-centered jerk and stays that way throughout almost its entire run.  Even his one moment of heroism before getting the powers is self-centered and based around his own issues.  He’s not pure of heart or spirit.  And yes his life has been tough and isolating and vicious, and I’m not saying what he’s been through is something you can just shrug off, but the entire point of his character is supposed to be his continued brightness despite all that he has been through.   There were jokes throughout, and there were some lighthearted scenes of Billy screwing around with his powers as he and Freddy figured them out, but they were isolated moments of levity instead of being the basis of the story.

I’ve got some issues with the Justice League Unlimited episode “The Clash”, but at least they captured what he’s supposed to be about.

trail.content:

Billy Batson starts the movie as a self-centered jerk and stays that way throughout almost its entire run.  Even his one moment of heroism before getting the powers is self-centered and based around his own issues.  He’s not pure of heart or spirit.  And yes his life has been tough and isolating and vicious, and I’m not saying what he’s been through is something you can just shrug off, but the entire point of his character is supposed to be his continued brightness despite all that he has been through.   There were jokes throughout, and there were some lighthearted scenes of Billy screwing around with his powers as he and Freddy figured them out, but they were isolated moments of levity instead of being the basis of the story.

I’ve got some issues with the Justice League Unlimited episode “The Clash”, but at least they captured what he’s supposed to be about.

Plus, the Wizard is flat-out responsible for Sivana turning into a villain, no ifs-ands-or-buts.  It’s going to fuck up any kid to be whisked away by a wizard and told that he would never be worthy, even if he wasn’t in a car crash immediately afterwards that his jerk father and brother blame on him.

tags: La Llorona - Le Lacrime del Male
summary: Box Office Usa - L'horror La Llorona vince un weekend pasquale da incassi deludenti
title: Box Office Usa - L'horror La Llorona vince un weekend pasquale da incassi deludenti
body:
Box Office Usa – L’horror La Llorona vince un weekend pasquale da incassi deludenti

Quello appena passato è da considerare il peggior Box Office Usa degli ultimi 10 anni nelle feste pasquali. Vince con oltre 25 milioni l’horror La Llorona.

James Wan ed il suo ConjuringVerse continuano a regalare soddisfazioni dal punto di vista economico. La Llorona – Le Lacrime del Maleha sorpreso gli analisti piazzando un weekend d’esordio da 26,5 milioni di dollari, ben oltre i 15 milioni…

View On WordPress

blog.description: terfs, swerfs, and aphobes fuck off. my side blog for all social justice stuff. blogs with NSFW icons will be blocked. mostly runs on a queue. if you wanna talk to me please send an ask or message bc I get so many notifs that I'll never see it otherwise. feminism, pro-choice and all that.

summary: Subtle Forms of Racism to Avoid in SFF
title: Subtle Forms of Racism to Avoid in SFF
description:
By Helen Gould. 

Now, a confession: I have stopped watching Game of Thrones. I couldn’t take the constant death any more. But, before I stopped, I watched quite a lot of Daenerys Targaryen’s white saviourism in Essos. It was incredibly annoying. I’m sure you’ve seen [the image above before.]

Think about how many fantasy books have a white society which is corrupt, and then a “brown” society which is even worse. For example, in Game of Thrones, there’s almost a sense of ‘you think Westeros is bad? Get a load of this!’. On that point, one thing that I have noticed with authors who write like this is that often, the non-European places still have slaves. It’s fascinating to me that this seems to be the sign of an eastern or southern society: that slavery is still embraced there. And yet, who was it who began the chattel slave trade?

My suspicion is that this particular phenomenon is a sort of displacement of blame; the white writer knows the history of slavery, and it is a horrible knowledge. So they write a place where the white society doesn’t have slaves and the brown one does, as if to say, ‘see? They’re as bad as us’. Except they’ve had to make it up.

And indeed, often we come back to this picture: a non-western civilisation is full of corruption and poverty and pain, and a white protagonist saves the grateful people. Just like Flaubert and the courtesan, the people in these places have no real voices other than pleas for help.

Read More

trail.content:
